headline.main: Think Like a Doctor: A Hideous Sore

docs.abstract: Solve a real-life medical mystery: A young doctor develops a repulsive rash on her arm. Then her boyfriend gets it, too.
docs.snippet: Solve a real-life medical mystery: A young doctor develops a repulsive rash on her arm. Then her boyfriend gets it, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: In 2002, a public hospital physician named Bill Cassidy donated to Democratic Sen. Mary Landrieu's first re-election campaign. A year later, he used a newspaper letter to the editor to criticize Republican gubernatorial candidate Bobby Jindal as a disaster for Louisiana's health care system.

headline.main: La.'s Cassidy: What Kind of Senator Would He Be?
headline.print_headline: La.'s Cassidy: What Kind of Senator Would He Be?

docs.lead_paragraph: A government report contains evidence that the U.S. health care system may be changing in ways that could make it more affordable in the years to come.

headline.main: Good News Inside the Health Spending Numbers

docs.snippet: A government report contains evidence that the U.S. health care system may be changing in ways that could make it more affordable in the years to come.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The data for 2013 did not show, however, whether cost controls in the Affordable Care Act or the aftereffects of the recession were responsible for the slowdown.
docs.abstract: Obama administration reports health care spending in United States totaled $2.9 trillion in 2013, up 3.6 percent from 2012; is lowest rate of increase since government started tracking it in 1960.
docs.snippet: The data for 2013 did not show, however, whether cost controls in the Affordable Care Act or the aftereffects of the recession were responsible for the slowdown.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve says that more than 30 percent of Americans report irregular incomes that sabotage efforts to budget and save. Unreliable work hours are cited most often.

headline.main: Unsteady Incomes Keep Millions Behind on Bills

docs.abstract: Financial volatility is a feature of life for millions of American workers whose paychecks fluctuate with the season, hourly schedule or size of a weekly commission; Federal Reserve survey based on 2013 data suggests problem has not only persisted as economy recovers but may even have worsened, with more than 30 percent of Americans reporting spikes and dips in their incomes.
docs.snippet: The Federal Reserve says that more than 30 percent of Americans report irregular incomes that sabotage efforts to budget and save. Unreliable work hours are cited most often.

docs.lead_paragraph: The second week of open enrollment in 2015 health insurance plans offered under President Barack Obama's healthcare reform almost matched the pace of the first week, federal health officials said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Enrollment in Obamacare Plans for 2015 Remains Strong
headline.print_headline: Enrollment in Obamacare Plans for 2015 Remains Strong

docs.snippet: The second week of open enrollment in 2015 health insurance plans offered under President Barack Obama's healthcare reform almost matched the pace of the first week, federal health officials said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance sign-ups through HealthCare.gov slowed over Thanksgiving week, the Obama administration said Wednesday. But they're not hitting the panic button yet.

headline.main: Health Law Sign-Ups Slowed Over Thanksgiving
headline.print_headline: Health Law Sign-Ups Slowed Over Thanksgiving

docs.snippet: Health insurance sign-ups through HealthCare.gov slowed over Thanksgiving week, the Obama administration said Wednesday. But they're not hitting the panic button yet.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. health care spending grew by the slowest rate in more than a half-century last year, government analysts said Wednesday. But a speed-up is coming as the economy gets traction and the new health care law covers more people.

headline.main: Growth for US Health Tab May Have Hit Bottom

docs.lead_paragraph: Early December may be the least wonderful time of the year for Medicare Advantage customers who still haven't settled on coverage plans for 2015.
docs.snippet: Early December may be the least wonderful time of the year for Medicare Advantage customers who still haven't settled on coverage plans for 2015.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of Medicare Advantage customers are fast approaching a deadline for a task they'd rather avoid: Researching and then settling on coverage plans for 2015.
